J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Again, I think that's already true. Look at the number of extensions 
> there are out there. Just because they're not in JUnit's contrib/ 
> directory doesn't make them any less contributions to JUnit.

No, it means there's no apparent way to get them committed. Scott 
Sterling has been sitting on a classloader fix for heaven knows how 
long. Calling working around the fact that Junit is inactive 
"contributions" to Junit is quite bizarre.

I'd direct you to Ant as an example of an open source project that 
accepts contributions; a project by the way that probably has more 
users that Junit but is at least being actively improved and worked on.

cheers
Bill
